I need to choose a move that keeps me alive, avoids running into my own tail, and leaves as many future options open as possible.

- **Self‑collision check:**  
  - **DOWN** would move my head onto (4, 7), which is currently my own body segment → instant death.  
  - **UP**, **LEFT**, and **RIGHT** all lead to empty squares, so they are safe with respect to my own body.

- **Board limits:**  
  - Moving **UP** would place my head at (4, 9), the top row. From there I could only go left or right on the next turn, dramatically narrowing my options.  
  - Moving **LEFT** to (3, 8) keeps me one step away from the left edge while still allowing moves **UP**, **DOWN**, or **LEFT** next turn (the only forbidden move would be back to (4, 8), which is currently my tail). This gives me three viable directions for the following turn.  
  - Moving **RIGHT** to (5, 8) mirrors the same limitation as moving left, but it pushes me toward the right wall with fewer apples nearby.

- **Apple proximity & strategy:**  
  - The closest apples are at (0, 7) and (2, 3); both lie roughly to the left‑down direction from my current position. Heading left moves me closer to those targets and keeps a clear path toward additional food.  
  - Enemy snake #1 is far to the right at (9, 6); none of my safe moves place me directly in its projected path, so no imminent head‑on collision is expected.

- **Future flexibility:**  
  - After a left move, my body will be [(3, 8), (4, 8)], leaving my tail at (4, 8). I can still move up, down, or further left without immediately self‑colliding, preserving multiple escape routes.  
  - Up or right moves would restrict my next move to only one direction (left or right respectively), increasing the risk of getting trapped later.

Considering all factors, the safest and most strategically advantageous move is to go **LEFT**.
